poem:
"Red Apples on the Pavement" 

Children pepper the cold London streets,
wrapped in swallowed poverty - unseen.
An honest cry for warmth and eats
lost in the labyrinth of politics' scene.
Five ideas bloom in a blank news sheet,
A chance for change, a corner turned?
Blossoming options in ink repeat,
a seed, cast lightly, waits to be learned.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "We can easily end child poverty in the UK. Here are five things to know What is the case for tackling child poverty? Can we make a dent in it? How? These questions have not been at the centre of British politics for the past 14 years, and the extent to which they will return to it under a Labour government remains to be seen. But they should. Here are five things anyone who wants to". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
